definition:
Let $\Gamma$ be a compact Lie group acting linearly on $V$ and let $g$
be a mapping defined as $g\colon V \to V$. Then $g$ is
*$\Gamma$-equivariant* if $$g(\gamma v)=\gamma g(v)$$ for all
$\gamma \in \Gamma$, and all $v \in V$.\
Therefore if $g$ commutes with $\Gamma$ then $g$ is
$\Gamma$-equivariant.

[@1]

[1]{} Golubitsky, Martin. Stewart, Ian. Schaeffer, G. David.:
Singularities and Groups in Bifurcation Theory *(Volume II)*.
Springer-Verlag, New York, 1988.
